node.title: make -j4 error

node.bodyText:
Hello
You are using a really old syntax for validParams. We no longer use templates for those
Please take a look at simple kernels code for an example
Guillaume

if you look at HeatConduction.C it uses the new syntax. In the .C file it should be
InputParameters
Conduction::validParams()
Thanks! I will try it.

node.title: Install PETSc on HPC
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I am trying to install moose on PSC (Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center), and I followed the tutorial on https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
But when I am installing PETSc, I got:
Now to install the library do:
make SLEPC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.slepc PETSC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts/../petsc install
=========================================
*** Installing SLEPc ***
*** Installing SLEPc at prefix location: /jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose  ***
====================================
Install complete.
Now to check if the libraries are working do (in current directory):
make SLEPC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose PETSC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts/../petsc PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose check
====================================
/usr/bin/gmake --no-print-directory -f makefile PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose PETSC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts/../petsc SLEPC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.slepc install-builtafterslepc
/usr/bin/gmake --no-print-directory -f makefile PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose PETSC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts/../petsc SLEPC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.slepc slepc4py-install
gmake[6]: Nothing to be done for 'slepc4py-install'.
=========================================
Now to check if the libraries are working do:
make PETSC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts/../petsc PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose check
=========================================
makefile:26: /jet/home/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc/lib/petsc/conf/rules.utils: No such file or directory
gmake[1]: *** No rule to make target '/jet/home/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc/lib/petsc/conf/rules.utils'.  Stop.
makefile:26: /jet/home/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc/lib/petsc/conf/rules.utils: No such file or directory
gmake[1]: *** No rule to make target '/jet/home/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc/lib/petsc/conf/rules.utils'.  Stop.
gmakefile.test:13: /jet/home/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc/arch-moose/lib/petsc/conf/petscvariables: No such file or directory
make: *** No rule to make target '/jet/home/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/scripts/../petsc/arch-moose/lib/petsc/conf/petscvariables'.  Stop.

Do you know what's going on and how to fix it?
@milljm

Since this step involves compilers for the first time in our instructions, we need to back up and verify how that looks. Can you run the following script and report the results?
cd /jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh
Please run this script after you have performed the "Activate Environment" step.
do you mean conda? I didn't use conda on HPC
I mean the "Activate Environment" step as listed on the instructions you linked, that you followed. I need you to perform that step again, before running the diagnostic script.

ok, diagnostics.sh gives:
Wed Sep 27 09:48:06 EDT 2023

System Arch: LSB Version: :core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch:cxx-4.1-amd64:cxx-4.1-noarch:desktop-4.1-amd64:desktop-4.1-noarch:languages-4.1-amd64:languages-4.1-noarch:printing-4.1-amd64:printing-4.1-noarch Distributor ID: CentOS Description: CentOS Linux release 8.2.2004 (Core) Release: 8.2.2004 Codename: Core

Looks pretty harmless up front. But lets be sure that some these are not getting in the way. Can you perform the following, and then try to build PETSc again:
mamba create -n testing -qy
mamba activate testing
(Creates and activates a blank Conda environment)
If an error occurs, can you then post the corresponding configure.log that it mentions? That log should be at:
/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/petsc/configure.log

thanks, it seems to be working now:
$ make PETSC_DIR=/jet/home/yliup/projects/moose/scripts/../petsc PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose check

Completed PETSc check examples

If I had to guess, it would be the following Conda packages that might have been getting in the way:
libstdcxx-ng              13.2.0               h7e041cc_2    conda-forge
ld_impl_linux-64          2.40                 h41732ed_0    conda-forge
libgcc-ng                 13.2.0               h807b86a_2    conda-forge
libgomp                   13.2.0               h807b86a_2    conda-forge

...or maybe one of the other lib* packages...
I will do following installation in the testing env

node.title: Multi-Scale Simulation Using Moose HeatTransfer and Phase Field Modules
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I'm exploring the implementation of a multi-scale simulation using Moose's HeatTransfer and Phase Field modules. The workflow entails computing the temperature field within a parent application. Subsequently, the temperature data from each unit will be transmitted to a child application. This child application will then utilize the received temperature data to execute a phase field simulation. Following the phase field simulation, the effective thermal conductivity will be computed based on the results obtained.
In this setup, each unit will run a phase field simulation independently. To manage this process, I plan to employ CentroidMultiApp to seamlessly integrate the child and parent applications.
However, the phase field represents a dynamic process where the computation of each phase field iteration relies on the results obtained from the previous step. Therefore, my concern pertains to whether CentroidMultiApp can ensure that the subsequent invocation of the phase field can accurately access the results from the previous iteration.
I welcome any insights or recommendations on how to ensure the smooth integration and continuity of results within this multi-scale simulation framework.

Hello

from the previous step

you mean time step right? Or do you mean fixed point iteration between the heat transfer and phase field simulations?
If you use a TransientMultiApp for the phase field  simulations, they will naturally restart from where they were on the previous step.
If you need these solves to be transients, you can specify a Transient executioner with no time derivative term, that is the same as a steady solve.
Guillaume
this is correct. Yes CentroidMultiApp will have the same behavior as TransientMultiApp in that regard.
note that if a multiapp at every element centroid is "too many" multiapps, you can use the 'positions' arguments of the transient multiapp instead
I tested the CentroidMultiApp ,you are right, thank you very much. :-)

node.title: Explicit Method for Large Deformation Model
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Since I would like to build a dislocation density coupled large deformation model, I wonder if it is possible to implement the explicit method to the solid mechanics model. Or is it possible to set the implicit = true while the time integrator is explicit so that I could have a time-explicit only model?
Also, I do not quite understand the linear solver and nonlinear solver in Moose. I am curious about what will the nonlinear solver do in an explicit method.
I do not know too much in this field, if my question is not clear, please let me know.
Best and Thanks,
zc

@FanZhangchen we have done some work on dislocation dynamics coupled with mechanics, the repository is here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am
and you can check our recent paper:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S002250962300039X
We have used explicit option in the kernels for dislocation transport,
however, I do not recommend to use explicit for the stress equilibrium equation.
You can keep the implicit formulation for the stress equilibrium, while using explicit to update other variables,
such as dislocation density.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

I am curious about what will the nonlinear solver do in an explicit method.

not much to do if  all the terms are explicit. But you still have an equation albeit fairly easy to solve.
There has been some work on simplifying the solve for fully explicit cases (see ActuallyExplicitEuler and the ExplicitTimeIntegrator time integrator code)

@ngrilli Thanks for your advice. That makes sense to me to use the explicit method for the dislocation density and use implicit for the stress equilibrium equation. I have read your paper and it is beneficial for me. We might meet similar numerical oscillations caused by the dislocation density transport equation and I am also trying to solve it with DG.
@GiudGiud Thanks for your reply. I will check the code. And I have another question about the off-diagonal terms in the stiffness matrix of Moose. Maybe I ignored some details, but I didn't find the document that describes how Moose treats the coupled off-diagonal terms. Are there any descriptions of how Moose obtains the coupled off-diagonal terms in the stiffness matrix? I just want to have a further understanding of the coupled terms in Moose. Thank you.

node.title: Negative Jacobian during reading mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I used Filemesh and FileMeshGenerator separately for the same problem, and the only difference in the input file is the mesh set.
Like this,
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = IFA-513r6_3D.e
  patch_size = 60
  patch_update_strategy = always
[]

[Mesh]

  patch_update_strategy = always
  [simple_mesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = IFA-513r6_3D.e
  []
  allow_renumbering = false
[]

    3  Node id()=544, processor_id()=3, Point=(x,y,z)=(-0.005455, -6.68045e-19, 0.810184)

libMesh terminating:
ERROR: negative Jacobian -3.9443e-31 at point (x,y,z)=(0.00136058, 0.000426164, 0.810184) in element 18446744073709551615
[3] ../src/fe/fe_map.C, line 903, compiled Sep  7 2023 at 15:19:38

So is it a problem with my mesh? Or why are the results so different?

Hello
there is a problem with the mesh. You have a flipped element, that s what the second error is saying. Does this happen on the very first time step? Or does this problem develop during the simulation?
you can use the meshDiagnosticsGenerator, another mesh generator to examine the mesh
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/MeshDiagnosticsGenerator.html
Guillaume

where is the output from the diagnostics for negative Jacobians in elements?
530 non-conformal nodes is definitely a problem, we only support non-conformality arising from uniform mesh refinement performed by libmesh

So I need to improve my mesh.

ok thanks.
the initial error is odd
ERROR: negative Jacobian -3.9443e-31 at point (x,y,z)=(0.00136058, 0.000426164, 0.810184) in element 18446744073709551615
there's a lot of signs that this is reading out of bounds because the id of the element is marked as invalid and then reported as a huge numbner.
Do you mind running this in a debugger and reporting a full backtrace?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

So I set allow_renumbering = true, the simulation could go on.

I put there.https://github.com/jin0123456/miniature-system
Though you may not be able to run it directly, using the mesh in a simple thermal conduction problem could work.

on a simple thermal conduction problem I am hitting
*** ERROR ***
CLI_ARGS:1.2:
The following error occurred in the Problem 'MOOSE Problem' of type FEProblem.

A libMesh::PetscSolverException was raised during FEProblemBase::computeJacobianTags
New nonzero at (2,6) caused a malloc
Use MatSetOption(A, MAT_NEW_NONZERO_ALLOCATION_ERR, PETSC_FALSE) to turn off this check


we can avoid it with this:
[Problem]
  error_on_jacobian_nonzero_reallocation = false
[]

or by turning the quadrature = true off in the GapHeatTransfer block.

node.title: Time stepper computed zero time step size on initial which is not allowed.
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose-Community,
In one of my Moose input files I defined two TimeSequenceSteppers and get the following error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "Executioner", of type "Transient".

Time stepper computed zero time step size on initial which is not allowed.
1. If you are using an existing time stepper, double check the values in your input file or report an error.
2. If you are developing a new time stepper, make sure that initial time step size in your code is computed correctly.

My Executioner-block looks like:
[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  end_time = 1.0
  [TimeSteppers]
    [TimeSequenceStepper1]
      type = TimeSequenceStepper
      time_sequence = '0.5'
    []
    [TimeSequenceStepper2]
      type = TimeSequenceStepper
      time_sequence = '0.0 0.2 0.4 1.0'
    []
  []

I would have expected, that Moose is merging the time steps into '0.0 0.2 0.4 0.5 1.0' rather than giving this error message. My impression from TimeStepper is that Moose should be merging. If I manually merge the two TimeSequenceStepper blocks, Moose works as expected. Is this intended behavior?

Hello

Is this intended behavior?

The error is the intended behavior. Specifying a solve at t=0 when you start at t=0 is disallowed.
The timesequencestepper was ignoring it somehow, but the combined time stepper sees it.
The combined time stepper does not merge the sequences. It polls the steppers for the next time step to take
Guillaume

node.title: Cahn-Hilliard not being coservative
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Community,
It is well known that Cahn-Hilliard equation is in conservative form, and it can be shown mathematically that with Neumann BC for the chemical potential, the integral of order parameter over the domain must be constant during time.
I noticed that within the Moose framework, this is not true on adaptive grids. What will be the best explanation for this behavior? Is there any good reference for this issue on adaptive grids?
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
Is the order parameter one of the variables of the solve?
When we perform steps of adaptivity, whether refinement or coarsening, we project the variables onto the new grid. Nonlinear quantities related to these variables would not be conserved by this process.
You could create a user object that enforces this conservation.
Guillaume

Thank you for your reply.
Yes, I perform adaptivity on the order parameter c and the conservation is lost.
I solve the issue of losing the convergence in another way. Right now I am mainly looking for a way to describe why exactly conservation is lost on adaptive grids (is it related to the interpolation of the variables to the new grid?) and whether this is a common issue in finite element method with h-refinement.
Also, does this happen to all of the non-linear variables in the system? (5 other variables apart from order parameter including velocity components, pressure, chemical potential)
And if there is any reference that I can cite and refer to about this issue it is highly appreciated.
Thanks.

Is 'c' one of the nonlinear variables?
What finite element family and order is it?

Yes, it is.
Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                115298
  Num Local DOFs:          9940
  Variables:               { "vel_x" "vel_y" "p" "c" "w" "rho_e" "phi" }
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE"  
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"

So when refining, we should easily conserve the integral of c.
When coarsening, I would expect us to minimize the L2 difference but we ll have to check libmesh to be sure

I think you are right. I am adding this MOOSE input file for test purposes.
When there is no mesh coarsening and just h-refinement, it seems that solution is conserved. But when coarsening is enabled (set it more than 0.0 in the adaptivity part of the input file), then the solution is not conservative.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 50
  ny = 50
  nz = 0
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 250
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 250
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 0
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]

[Variables]
  [./c]
  [../]
  [./w]
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./local_free_energy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./cIC]
    type = SmoothCircleIC
    variable = c
    x1 = 125.0
    y1 = 125.0
    radius = 60.0
    invalue = 1.0
    outvalue = 0.1
    int_width = 30.0
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./c_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c
    f_name = F
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w
  [../]
  [./w_res]
    type = SplitCHWRes
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
  [../]
  [./time]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = c
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./local_free_energy]
    type = TotalFreeEnergy
    variable = local_free_energy
    kappa_names = kappa_c
    interfacial_vars = c
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./pfmobility]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'M kappa_c'
    prop_values = '1e-3 0.1'
  [../]
  [./free_energy]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables = c
    constant_names = 'barr_height  cv_eq'
    constant_expressions = '0.1          1.0e-2'
    expression = 16*barr_height*(c-cv_eq)^2*(1-cv_eq-c)^2
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]

  [./total_free_energy]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = local_free_energy
  [../]

    [./total_solutec]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = c
    execute_on = linear

  [../]


[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = -pc_type
  petsc_options_value = lu
  l_max_its = 30
  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-10
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 60
  dt = 200
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  exodus = true
[]

[Adaptivity]
  initial_steps = 2
  steps = 1
  marker = error
  [Indicators]
    [jump]
      type = GradientJumpIndicator
      variable = c
     outputs = none

    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [error]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
     coarsen = 0.50
      refine = 0.90
      indicator = jump
      outputs = none
    []
  []
 max_h_level = 2
[]

@roystgnr could you please point us to the docs for h-coarsening of variables in libmesh?
I see the code for coarsening elements in MeshRefinement. Is the code for the projection during coarsening in the GenericProjector?

This input file from MOOSE tests shows it better.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 100
  ny = 100
  xmax = 30.0
  ymax = 30.0
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]

[Variables]
  [./c]
  [../]
  [./w]
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./c_IC]
    type = CrossIC
    x1 = 0.0
    x2 = 30.0
    y1 = 0.0
    y2 = 30.0
    variable = c
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./cres]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w
    f_name = F
  [../]
  [./wres]
    type = SplitCHWRes
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
    coupled_variables = c
  [../]
  [./time]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = c
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./Periodic]
    [./all]
      auto_direction = 'x y'
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./kappa]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'kappa_c'
    prop_values = '2e-2'
  [../]
  [./mob]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = M
    coupled_variables = c
    expression = '1-0.9*c^2'
    outputs = exodus
    derivative_order = 1
  [../]
  [./free_energy]
    type = MathEBFreeEnergy
    property_name = F
    c = c
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
   type = SMP
   off_diag_row = 'w c'
   off_diag_column = 'c w'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = 'BDF2'

  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm         31      lu      1'

  l_max_its = 30
  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_max_its = 50
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-10

  dt = 1.0
  num_steps = 20
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

[Postprocessors]


  # for testing we also monitor the total solute amount, which should be conserved.


    [./total_solutec]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = c

  [../]
  []

  [Adaptivity]
  initial_steps = 1
  steps = 1
  marker = error
  [Indicators]
    [jump]
      type = GradientJumpIndicator
      variable = c
     outputs = none

    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [error]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
     coarsen = 0.90
      refine = 0.90
      indicator = jump
      outputs = none
    []
  []
 max_h_level = 1
[]

It's GenericProjector that does the refinement and coarsening.  In either case the algorithm is the same: interpolate values (and for C1 elements gradients, and for HERMITE elements gradient cross terms) at nodes, then project (L2 for C0 elements, H1 for C1) along edges holding nodes fixed, then project along faces holding edges and nodes fixed, then project on interiors holding boundaries fixed.
For refinement, this gives you the same value (up to floating point error) for p-refinement and for h-refinement in any FEFamily that has a nested space (everything except CLOUGH, in libMesh).
For coarsening, this totally breaks conservation.  Picture the simplest case, 1D p=1.  You have a coarse element that's linear between its two end points, you set its endpoints equal to what the two fine elements had ... and now you're done; there's no other DoFs to set.  If the coarsened-away node's value was higher than the average of its neighbors then you've just subtracted mass to nowhere, if lower you've just added mass from nowhere.
The only alternatives are non-local (as is fairly easy to see in this case - you can't tweak those end node values without worrying about how it affects conservation on their neighbors, and how to compensate for that without breaking their neighbors...). E.g. doing a global L2 projection rather than a bunch of local ones would be conservative ... but the problem in that case is that you can more easily get something like Gibbs' ringing effects; there's no free lunch once you start shrinking your approximation space.
Thanks. It was explained very well :)

Is there any reference that I can cite or refer to for this numerical problem? @roystgnr
Thanks,

node.title: Adding lagrange multiplier to the Cahn-Hilliard equation in the split form
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE community,
I added the scalar Lagrange multiplier to enforce a constraint on the volume integral of order parameter. Can someone please explain to me what additional term is added to the original Cahn-Hilliard equation by adding this constraint? Attached is the relevant part of the input file.
@jiangwen84 @GiudGiud
[Variables]
  [./c]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    [./InitialCondition]
    type = SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC
    variable = c
    x_positions = '0'
    y_positions = '0'
    z_positions = '0'
    radii = '${R}'
    invalue = 1
    outvalue = -1
    int_width = ${epsilon3}
  [../]
[]
  [./w]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
  [./lambdac]
    family = SCALAR
    order = FIRST
 [../]
[]

[ScalarKernels]
 [./mean_zero_pressure_c]
    type = AverageValueConstraint
   variable = lambdac
    pp_name = total_solutec
  value =   -4.572052e-03
[]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./mean_zero_c]
  type = ScalarLagrangeMultiplier
  variable = c
   lambda = lambdac
 [../]
  [./c_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c
    f_name = F
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w
  [../]

  [./w_res]
    type =  SplitCHWResAniso #SplitCHWRes
    variable = w
    mob_name = M_c
  [../]
  [./time]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = c
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
    [./total_solutec]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = c
    execute_on = linear
[]

Thanks,

Hello
Adding a constraint (that way) is like adding an additional equation that gets solved simultaneously by the nonlinear solver.
You do not need to change the original equations for that
Having the AverageValueConstraint and the ScalarLagrangeMultiplier kernels looks fine to me
Guillaume

Thanks.
My understanding is that the strong form of the equations remain intact. However, additional term appears in residual term for the order parameter according the (https://github.com/idaholab/large_media/blob/master/framework/scalar_constraint_kernel.pdf). Am I correct?
Regards,
if you look at the end of that document, the extra term (9) in the residual is added by the ScalarLagrangeMultiplier kernel which you already have

node.title: AdvancedExtruderGenerator skipping radial nodes?
node.bodyText:
I am trying to make a pipe in moose and have made the circle in 2D using the annularmeshgenerator. However when I use the AdvancedExtruderGenerator to extrude, I lose some of the rings of nodes that are in the original circle. I have tried a bunch of the other commands and feel like I'm missing something?
[Mesh]
  [face1]
      type = AnnularMeshGenerator
      rmin = 0 # makes plane a disk instead of a ring
      rmax = .5 # sets the radius from the center for the outer ring, r=.5 means diameter is 1 which is beam spot size.
      nt = 10 # number of notes along outer ring 
      nr = 3 # number of nodes between the center and the outer radius. (increase later but small now for speed of tests)
  []
  
  [extrude]
      type = AdvancedExtruderGenerator
      input = face1
      heights = '1 2'
      num_layers = '1 1 '
      direction = '0 0 1'
      biases = '1 2'
  []
[]
Can you check that by clipping the mesh in the middle? I would do more checks to confirm that these elements and nodes are missing.

hello
This is just wireframe not showing the inner nodes.
use surface with edges instead in the selector (center top of the screen, it defaults to surface usually)

[0] ../src/fe/fe_map.C, line 1138, compiled Sep  7 2023 at 15:19:38

Hello
This happens when an element gets flipped and/or distorted such that the Jacobian (the one of the transformation from the reference element) is negative.
Use a checkpoint to recover right before this point and try a smaller time step
Guillaume
How do you use checkpoints to recover right before this point I am encountering a similar problem. @navier-rgb @GiudGiud

turn on checkpoint = true in the Outputs block
then you can add on the command line --recover the second time you run the input to restart from there.
That's one way. There's a page here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html
It did not solve my issue. I have also submitted a ticket on my issue here:#27363
